title: 106_hr5032
content: The "Caribbean Amnesty and Relief Act" clarifies eligibility for relief from removal and deportation for certain Caribbean aliens by allowing adjustment of status for specific individuals. The "Caribbean Amnesty and Relief Act" allows for the adjustment of status for eligible aliens to obtain permanent residence, bypassing certain grounds for inadmissibility. The "Caribbean Amnesty and Relief Act" allows eligible aliens with certain orders to apply for adjustment of status without needing to file a separate motion. If the application is granted, the order will be canceled; if denied, the order remains enforceable. Aliens from Caribbean countries can apply for adjustment of status if they have been physically present in the US since September 30, 1996, with absences not exceeding 180 days. Proof of continuous presence is required for the application. Aliens from Caribbean countries can apply for adjustment of status if they have been physically present in the US since September 30, 1996, with absences not exceeding 180 days. The Attorney General may require proof of service or physical presence for aliens seeking a stay of deportation or removal. Aliens in exclusion, deportation, or removal proceedings can apply for adjustment of status under certain conditions. The Attorney General may authorize employment for these aliens during the application process, and for spouses and children as well. Adjustment of Status for Spouses and Children of aliens from Caribbean countries can be done by the Attorney General to grant permanent residence, with specific requirements for physical presence in the US since December 1, 1995. The Attorney General can grant permanent residence to spouses and children of aliens from Caribbean countries through adjustment of status, with specific requirements for physical presence in the US since December 1, 1995. The alien must apply for adjustment, be physically present in the US when the application is filed, be eligible for an immigrant visa, and not be subject to certain exclusion grounds. The application for adjustment must be filed before April 1, 2002. In 2002, aliens seeking adjustment of status must prove continuous physical presence since December 1, 1995, with allowances for absences of up to 180 days. The Attorney General must provide administrative review rights to applicants similar to those under section 245. The Attorney General's determination on alien status adjustment under section 245 or removal proceedings under section 240 is final and not subject to judicial review. When an alien is granted permanent residence status, the number of immigrant visas available is not reduced. The Immigration and Nationality Act provisions apply unless specified otherwise. The Immigration and Nationality Act definitions apply to this section. The Attorney General's powers in immigration enforcement are not affected. Eligibility for permanent residence status under this section does not prevent seeking it under other laws. The Visa Fairness Commission is established within the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Its duties are outlined in the legislation. The Visa Fairness Commission, in consultation with the Director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, collects data on economic and racial profiling at American embassies and US points of entry. The Secretary of State is required to waive visa fees for those in forma pauperis status. The Visa Fairness Commission is composed of 15 members appointed by the Director of the INS, representing diverse groups in the US. Appointments can bypass certain limitations, with a restriction on political party affiliation. Members serve two-year terms without pay, except for federal employees. The Commission members, who are full-time US officers or employees, cannot receive extra pay or benefits. Each member gets travel expenses as per US Code. Eight members form a quorum, with the Chairman and Vice Chairman appointed by the INS Director. Meetings are called by the Chairman or majority of members. SEC. 204. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission shall have a Director appointed by the Commission, who will be paid at a rate not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Director may appoint additional staff as needed, subject to Commission rules. The Director and staff will be appointed under title 5, United States Code, and paid according to General Schedule pay rates. The Director may procure temporary services under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code, at rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. SEC. 205. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and obtain necessary information from government agencies to carry out its duties. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and the Commission can accept gifts, bequests, and devises. The Commission has the authority to accept gifts, bequests, and devises of services or property to aid its work. It can also use the United States mails and request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. Additionally, the Commission has subpoena power. The Commission has subpoena power under the Act, allowing it to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to investigations. Failure to comply with a subpoena may result in a court order to appear before the Commission. The Commission has the power to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence. Failure to comply may result in civil contempt. Subpoenas must be served as per Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. Process serving can be done in the judicial district where the person resides. Immunity is not granted for refusing to testify or produce evidence. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas, and individuals can claim the privilege against self-incrimination. The Commission can also contract with government and private agencies for property and services without following certain statutes. The Commission is required to submit an annual report to the Director of the INS and Congress by December 31 each year, detailing its activities during the fiscal year. Additionally, there is authorization for appropriations to complete the study.
